On long-distance journeys, the bike also carries you through the country at the ideal travel speed: fast enough to circumnavigate the world and yet with enough leisure for an encounter and a conversation.

WeOnBikes.com â€“ Life by bicycle â€“ is: WeOnBikes.com - Life by bicycle - is our new project with which we are preparing our next bicycle tour from north to south through Europe. We would like to share our experiences with everyone who is interested in bikepacking and wants to know how to go about such a trip.

And a few kilometers back north, to our home. Thatâ€™s what weâ€™ve planned for 2023.
Und wenn man sich die beiden Routen so a: And if you look at the two routes, it's actually clear that the project isnâ€™t finished
Von Moskau zum Nordkap auf dem Fahrrad: From Moscow to the North Cape by bike
Mit Fahrrad und Zelt sind wir fernab vom: Far from tourist centers, we cycled from Russia to Karelia, through Finland and across the Arctic Circle with bikes and a tent. 3 countries separated us in Moscow from the northernmost point of the European continent. For 60 days we experienced adventures instead of everyday life and pedaled our bikes instead of the hamster wheel. The journey took us along 4000 kilometers of fresh air, full of interesting encounters and longing for the Barents Sea.

Radwandern im Nordosten Europas. 60 Tage: Bicycle touring in northeastern Europe. 60 days with bike and tent through Russia, Finland, Lapland and Norway. Exciting travellogue with many photos to get carried away. Download reading sample, gallery, GPS route.
Von Moskau Zum Nordkapp: From Moscow to the North Cape
Die OSM-Karte punktet heute besonders, w: The OSM map gets extra points today because it shows us where to get drinking water: Thereâ€™s a pump right next to the level crossing. Itâ€™s become quite hot, almost 30 degrees. We fill up everything we have. A man comes from his yard and wants to fill his buckets. Menno asks if he can take a photo. Sure, says Sergei, and invites us to tea.
Begegnungen, Gastfreundschaft, verlassen: Encounters, hospitality, abandoned villages and lonely stretches of land: this diary takes you on a 4000-kilometer journey through rarely visited corners of three countries in north-eastern Europe. With bikes and tent we cycle far away from tourism from Russia to Karelia, through Finland and across the Arctic Circle. Spring also moves north with us, complete with flower meadows, cuckoo calls and swarms of mosquitoes. For 60 days we experience adventure instead of everyday life, and pedal our bikes instead of the hamster wheel.

He recommends that we buy paper maps and points to the bookshop on the corner. He wouldâ€™ve shown us on a papermap the sights in Oblast Moscow we absolutely shouldnâ€™t miss. He finds our OSM app suspect and thinks weâ€™re unprepared for such a difficult tour. I end up asking him if he knows where we can get denatured alcohol. No, we donâ€™t have that here.â€ This probably confirms his impression regarding our preparations: No paper maps, and no fuel. Not to mention our limited knowledge of Russian. Verkehrstechnisch geht es heute besser a: The traffic is going better today than yesterday. Itâ€™s quieter, and weâ€™re also getting used to it. We stop at a gas station where I buy some water and two Mars bars and accidentally pay for the next customerâ€™s gas. The cashier had been grumpily counting the cash for the shift change, and hadnâ€™t noticed our bicycles or me at her window. So she has no idea that I donâ€™t want gasoline, or that I might be a foreigner who doesnâ€™t understand her. She mumbles something in my direction, which I interpret as â€œwith a card?â€, and I indicate yes. It was a misunderstanding: Sheâ€™d been asking about the number of the pump. I look at the high amount on my credit card receipt (she hadnâ€™t used the cash register) while the next customer tries unsuccessfully to pay for his gas. Total confusion ensues, especially since I paid by card. The cashier looks up from her pile of money, sees me and the bicycles and finally gets it. Her bad mood gets worse. Sheâ€™s in absolutely no condition today to be able to solve my problem, so she just gives us a pissed-off stare.

Tag 4 Malachowo â€“ Uglitsch â€“ Utschma: Day 4 Malakhovo â€“ Uglich â€“ Uchma, 68â€¯km
Am spÃ¤ten Nachmittag sehen wir ein Schi: In the late afternoon, we spot a sign saying Museum village. The place is called Uchma. Weâ€™re in a sightseeing mood, so we take the turn and drive through a normal little village with one or two paths and arrive at the penultimate courtyard of the museum. There are many wooden houses on this somewhat small area, not painted in the usual bright colors, but rather in their natural state, with the typical nalitchniki, the elaborate decorations on window panes and gables.
Wir stellen die RÃ¤der auf dem Weg vor d: We park our bikes on the way to the entrance and open the gate. A big dog lies sluggishly in the sun and blinks at us. The afternoon sun bathes the ensemble in a golden light as a couple of geese wobble across the grass. The terrain slopes down to the river, merging seamlessly into swamp and then into the Volga. We hear film sounds coming from one of the buildings and open the door. Weâ€™re received by a woman who speaks English. Now weâ€™re in the Russian Village Museum, which depicts village life in post-war Russia up to Perestroika. There had been livestock and fishing here, and of course agriculture. We look at tools, clothes and furniture from that period and take funny photos with Soviet accessories.
Uta steht hinter der Theke des Ladens au: Uta stands behind the counter of the shop from the old days and plays with the abacus. You can see products from the past and an old scale.
Einkaufen frÃ¼her: im Netz die Papirossy: Shopping in the past: in a net the Papirossy, an abacus instead of a cash register
Hier gab es Viehzucht und Fischerei. Lan: â€œNowadays nobody fishes here,â€ says the woman from the museum. Commercial fishing is even prohibited. Thereâ€™s no more agriculture either, â€œ a tragedy for Russia,â€ she says. Maybe I should tell her about the organic farmer 70â€¯km south? What sheâ€™s probably referring to is that thereâ€™s no fruit or vegetables from Russia in the supermarkets, which weâ€™d already noticed. Even in small shops, fruit and vegetables are very limited because nothing grows here at this time of the year.
Vermutlich will sie darauf hinaus, dass: Naturally she wants to know what brought us here and what our route looks like. Menno is about to show her on his phone when he realizes he left it in the bikeâ€™s holder.

So fahren wir zur FÃ¤hre und warten bis: So we drive to the ferry and wait until 6 p.m. There are already quite a few people waiting, all with bulk purchases, many with plants. A woman asks me if I can keep an eye on her bags. Yes, of course. When she comes back, she starts interrogating us. Where from, where to, why. She says she is from Finnish Karelia, lives here in Petrozavodsk and has a dacha in Kizhi. Thatâ€™s where sheâ€™s headed now. She wants to know exactly where our journey will take us. Somehow sheâ€™s not really happy with my answers. She points to Menno: ĞĞ½ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğµ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ñ‚ Ğ¿Ğ¾-Ñ€ÑƒÑÑĞºĞ¸? (on tosche nje govorit po russki), he also doesnâ€™t speak Russian? No, I say.
Sie habe diesen Artikel anlÃ¤sslich der: Then she pulls an 8-fold Karelian newspaper out of her medium-sized womanâ€™s handbag and holds the Finnish-language front page under my nose. Here, thatâ€™s me, she says. Then she speaks Finnish. I assure her in German that my Finnish is undoubtedly even worse than my Russian and she switches back again. I understand that she wrote this article on the occasion of the May 9 demonstration, which is pictured on the front page. In the picture, sheâ€™s holding up a sign with a photo from the forties of a young woman. Her sister, she explains, a doctor, very pretty. Then there are dates and war events that I canâ€™t follow. Even after studying the Wikipedia article, Karelia as a republic remains a fuzzy autonomous region for us, which seems to be the result of several fuzzy wars.
Immerhin erkenne ich, dass ich eine Regi: In any case, I recognize that Iâ€™m looking at a regional patriot. Yes, I say, and fear that Menno is not sporting the appropriate facial expression. Do you have children? No. Do you want some? A minefield! In Lachkolampi wollen wir Eis kaufen. Wi: In Lahkolampi we go to buy ice cream. Weâ€™re standing in line when a man in a uniform and a uniform cap comes in and barks something. Besides us and the saleswoman thereâ€™s a woman, a couple, and three children whoâ€™ve been hanging around since our arrival, holding chocolate bars and inspecting us curiously. The uniformed guy speaks directly to me. I tell him I donâ€™t speak Russian. He says another sentence which I donâ€™t understand, probably official Russian, something like: â€œIdentify yourself!â€ Is it as funny and ambiguous in Russian as it is in German, where it could also mean: â€œDeport yourselfâ€? â€œPassport,â€ he then remembers.

Radwandern: was kostet es, muss ich trai: Bicycle touring: what are the costs, do I have to train, which repair tools for by bike? Here you will find quick answers about cycling trips and our journey from Moscow to the North Cape by bicycle.
Ist Fahrradfahren eine gute Art zu reise: Is cycling a good way to travel?
Ja. Hier die Vorteile: #1 Du brauchst de: Yes. Here are the advantages: #1 You donâ€™t have to carry your backpack on your back like you do on other trips. #2 You save the expense of gasoline and spare your nerves from car traffic. #3 You can physically and mentally relax better on a bike than in a car. #4 The pace of travel is perfect: You get to see a lot of the landscape, you can meet people on the way and still get where youâ€™re going. And if you get lost, correcting the route is quicker than on foot.
Du brauchst dein GepÃ¤ck nicht auf dem R: You donâ€™t have to carry your backpack on your back like you do on other trips.
Du sparst die Kosten fÃ¼r Benzin und die: You save the expense of gasoline and spare your nerves from car traffic.
KÃ¶rperlich und mental kannst du dich au: You can physically and mentally relax better on a bike than in a car.
Deine Reisegeschwindigkeit ist perfekt:: The pace of travel is perfect: You get to see a lot of the landscape, you can meet people on the way and still get where youâ€™re going. And if you get lost, correcting the route is quicker than on foot.
Wie weit kann man mit dem Fahrrad an ein: How far can you travel by bicycle per day?
Wir schaffen in bergigem Gebiet oder off: We travel some 50 km if we are in the mountains or off-road. On blacktop we make about 100 km, depending on the amount of luggage and wind.
Wie war die Erfahrung in kÃ¶rperlicher H: What was the physical experience on a long-distance bicycle trip?
Wir sind untrainiert los. Die ersten paa: We set off without training, so the first few days were accompanied by sore muscles ğŸ™‚ However, we are used to cycling and are pretty fit, so we weren't completely drained.Â  The movement has done us good.Â Deep sand paths with steep inclines were exhausting.Â  If you have to push your bike uphill, it sometimes makes sense to carry the luggage up the hill without the bike, or to carry the luggage on your back so that the bike doesn't sink so deep.Â  Sunscreen and hats protected us from the sun.Â When it was hot, we just took a longer lunch break.Â  After all, we were on vacation!
Macht euch Fahrradurlaub zusammen glÃ¼ck: Does a bicycle vacation together makes you happier?
Ja. In gemÃ¼tlicher Reisegeschwindigkeit: Yes.Â Depending on the route, we can ride side by side at a comfortable cruising speed and chat, sing or just enjoy the ride.Â Getting space from each other once in a while is not a problem either.Â We get to know people together and we experience enriching experiences together - even the less pleasant ones.Â  We constantly discuss the route and then constantly change our minds.Â  We motivate, help and inspire each other.Â In everyday life at home, with the steady stream of everyday problems, the relationship can get stressed and suffer before you know it.Â On a cycling holiday, on the other hand, everyday life takes a back seat, and the happy moments are in the limelight.
Wie lange habt ihr diese Tour im Voraus: How long did you plan for this trip from Moscow to the North Cape?
6 Monate vor der Reise hatten wir die Id: We had the idea 6 months before the trip and then it took us a month to agree on the direction and the starting point.Â  About 5 months before we booked flights.Â  We could only apply for the visa for Russia a month in advance.
Wie viel hat eure Fahrradreise von 60 Ta: How much did the bicycle tour of days cost?
3500 Euro insgesamt zu zweit. Ein Fahrra: 3500 euros in total for two.Â  We had to buy a bike beforehand (used) = 450 euros.Â  Flights to Moscow = 360 euros, flights home from the North Cape = 500 euros, 160 euros to buy equipment, including sleeping bags, 2 extra packing bags, hats, stove, gas.Â  We spent about 300 euros in restaurants and about 600 euros for accommodation.Â  So there is a possibility to spend less. ğŸ™‚ Then about 1000 euros for the supermarket and other things.Â  That was in 2018.
Ja. Das gute am Reisen per Rad ist, dass: Yes.Â The good thing about traveling by bike is that it can be customized.Â Not particularly fit?Â Just drive shorter stages.Â No idea about technology?Â Choose a route near civilization.Â  Your knees don't want to work so hard?Â Just ride in a flat area or get an e-bike.Â  Allergic to rain?Â Pick a dry season. Donâ€™t have much money?Â With a tent and stove, you can get really far even on a micro-budget.
Dem musst du unbedingt vorbeugen! Zwei g: You absolutely have to prevent this! With two well-fitting cycling pants and the right saddle you shouldn't have any problems. You should definitely test your saddle beforehand.Â The smaller the seating area, the less it can chafe.Â But the seat angle also plays a role.Â If you get sore spots, find the caue and correct it immediately.Â Because once you get sore, the fun is over for a long time.
Muss ich Ahnung von Fahrradreparatur hab: Do I have to know anything about bike repairs if I go on a bike tour?
Ein bisschen. Einfache Reparaturen sollt: A bit. You should be able to carry out simple repairs: patching hoses, readjusting the brakes and adjusting the gears are the most important.Â You need an air pump, repair kit and (depending on the bike) the right keys.
Wo finde ich die besten Routen?: Where can I find the best routes?
Open Street Map ist gratis, funktioniert: Open Street Map is free, works offline and has a bike map mode.Â  There are many other apps, free and paid, that you can use to plan your route. Make sure you can download the maps to use them without internet.
